ygData.subject: Re: test suite v 0.99
ygData.msgSnippet: Below are some problems stackarchiveorg was kind enough to report while testing the crawler test suite.  The reported bugs (I belive) have been addressed, but

Below are some problems stackarchiveorg was kind enough to report while
testing the crawler test suite.  The reported bugs (I belive) have been
addressed, but a few questions he posed have answers that may be useful to
everyone.

Updated code is running on my site:

 http://parkert.com/crawlertest/

On Wed, 28 Jan 2004, stackarchiveorg wrote:

|+ I added a crawler.  Its named heritrix too but had a different 
|version.  In drop down it only shows the crawler name, not version, so 
|its hard for me to distingush between the two.

This may be the first usability problem.  The app has a notion of a
crawler, which then has versions, i.e. a crawler Heritrix has versions 1
and 2.  You were trying to treat a crawler as an entity with a version,
i.e. there is a crawler Heritrix version 1.  Crawls are then started using
a specific version, or the latest if no version is specified.

Sorry, this is just slightly confusing, but makes data processing easier
(like comparing versions of a crawler).

If you want to add a version of an existing crawler, like Heritrix 5.0,
edit the crawler and add the version there.  You could get around this
functionality by just creating a new crawler "Heritrix v 5.0" and most
everything would work just fine, you just would not be able to use the
"view crawler results" page to compare versions.

|+ I see on disk and in your commit of last night that tests on the 
|filesystem are named 'test1', 'test3' etc.  Do they have to be named 
|so?  Could they have more meaningful names so the 'background image 
|extraction' test (test1) was  contained in a directory named 
|'bkgrd_image_extraction' or some such.

No, you can call them anything you like.  In the old version we used this 
naming convention to make parsing apache logs easier and I just didn't 
bother to give them new names here.  But as we add new tests they can have 
any directory names you like.

|+ Whats 'webroot' in the 'Add Test' page?

webroot is the name of the test's root directory, e.g. 'test1'.  To add a
test you first dump a directory (e.g. newtest/) into
<crawlertesthome>/tests/, then use the web form and specify a 'webroot'
(e.g. 'newtest').  

Rules are then defined relative to this root, so you might have a rule
"FIND hidden.html" which would require that the crawler find
<crawlertesthome>/tests/newtest/hidden.html.  Make sense?

Also, there is no requirement that all tests be directly under the test
root (<crawlertesthome>/tests/), so you can nest directories if it makes
sense to organize tests hierarchically on the filesystem.

Oh, and I belive someone ask recently about instructions.  What exists can 
be found here:

  http://parkert.com/crawlertest/usageinstructions.txt

Let me know if you have any other questions or bug reports,

pt.
--
Parker Thompson
The Internet Archive
510.541.0125
